To make your speed to Dover, you shall find
Some that will thank you, making just report
Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow
The king hath cause to plain.
I am a gentleman of blood and breeding;
And, from some knowledge and assurance, offer
This office to you.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: I will talk further with you.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: No, do not.
For confirmation that I am much more
Than my out-wall, open this purse and take
What it contains. If you shall see Cordelia, —
As fear not but you shall, — show her this ring;
And she will tell you who that fellow is
That yet you do not know. Fie on this storm!
I will go seek the king.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Give me your hand: have you no more to say?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Few words, but, to effect, more than all yet;
That, when we have found the king, — in which, your pain
That way, I'll this, — he that first lights on him
Holla the other. Exeunt severally.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 2
div.stage: Another part of the heath. Storm still.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! rage! blow!
You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout
Till you have drenched our steeples, drowned the cocks!
You sulphurous and thought-executing fires,
Vaunt-couriers of oak-cleaving thunderbolts,
Singe my white head! And thou, all-shaking thunder,
Strike flat the thick rotundity o' the world!
Crack nature's moulds, all germens spill at once,
That makes ingrateful man!

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: O nuncle, court holy-water in a dry house is
better than this rain-water out o' door. Good
nuncle, in, ask thy daughters blessing: here's a night
pities neither wise men nor fools.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire! spout, rain!
Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire, are my daughters:
I tax not you, you elements with unkindness;
I never gave you kingdom, called you children,
You owe me no subscription: then let fall
Your horrible pleasure; here I stand, your slave,
A poor, infirm, weak, and despised old man:
But yet I call you servile ministers,
That will with two pernicious daughters join
Your high-engendered battles 'gainst a head
So old and white as this. O, ho! 'tis foul!

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: He that has a house to put's head in has a good
head-piece.

lg.l: The codpiece that will house
Before the head has any,
The head and he shall louse;
So beggars marry many.
The man that makes his toe
What he his heart should make
Shall of a corn cry woe,
And turn his sleep to wake.

sp.ab: For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths
in a glass.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: No, I will be the pattern of all patience;
I will say nothing. Enter KENT.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Marry, here's grace and a codpiece; that's a wise man
and a fool.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Alas, sir, are you here? things that love night
Love not such nights as these; the wrathful skies
Gallow the very wanderers of the dark,
And make them keep their caves: since I was man,
Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder,
Such groans of roaring wind and rain, I never
Remember to have heard: man's nature cannot carry
The affliction nor the fear.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Let the great gods,
That keep this dreadful pother o'er our heads,
Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch,
That hast within thee undivulged crimes,
Unwhipped of justice: hide thee, thou bloody hand;
Thou perjured, and thou simular of virtue
That art incestuous: caitiff, to pieces shake,
That under covert and convenient seeming
Has practised on man's life: close pent-up guilts,
Rive your concealing continents, and cry
These dreadful summoners grace. I am a man
More sinned against than sinning.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Alack, bareheaded!
Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel;
Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest:
Repose you there; while I to this hard house —
More harder than the stones whereof 'tis raised;
Which even but now, demanding after you,
Denied me to come in — return, and force
Their scanted courtesy.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: My wits begin to turn.
Come on, my boy: how dost, my boy? art cold?
I am cold myself. Where is this straw, my fellow?
The art of our necessities is strange,
And can make vile things precious. Come, your hovel.
Poor fool and knave, I have one part in my heart
That's sorry yet for thee.

lg.l: He that has and a little tiny wit, —
With heigh-ho, the wind and the rain, —
Must make content with his fortunes fit,
Though the rain it raineth every day.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: True, boy. Come, bring us to this hovel. Exeunt Lear and Kent.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: This is a brave night to cool a courtezan. I'll speak
a prophecy ere I go:

lg.l: When priests are more in word than matter;
When brewers mar their malt with water;
When nobles are their tailors' tutors;
No heretics burned, but wenches' suitors;
Then shall the realm of Albion
Come to great confusion.
When every case in law is right;
No squire in debt, nor no poor knight;
When slanders do not live in tongues;
Nor cutpurses come not to throngs;
When usurers tell their gold i' the field;
And bawds and whores do churches build;
Then comes the time, who lives to see't,
That going shall be used with feet.

sp.ab: This prophecy Merlin shall make; for I live before his
time.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.ab: Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural
dealing. When I desired their leave that I might
pity him, they took from me the use of mine own
house; charged me, on pain of perpetual displeasure,
neither to speak of him, entreat for him, or any way
sustain him.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.ab: Most savage and unnatural!

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.ab: Go to; say you nothing. There is division between
the dukes: and a worse matter than that: I have
received a letter this night; 'tis dangerous to
be spoken; I have locked the letter in my closet:
these injuries the king now bears will be revenged
home; there is part of a power already footed:
we must incline to the king. I will look him,
and privily relieve him: go you and maintain talk
with the duke, that my charity be not of him
perceived: if he ask for me, I am ill, and gone
to bed. If I die for't, as no less is threatened
me, the king my old master must be relieved.
There is strange things toward, Edmund; pray you, be
careful.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the duke
Instantly know; and of that letter too:
This seems a fair deserving, and must draw me
That which my father loses; no less than all.
The younger rises when the old doth fall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Here is the place, my lord; good my lord, enter:
The tyranny of the open night's too rough
For nature to endure. Storm still.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Good my lord, enter here.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Wilt break my heart?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: I had rather break mine own. Good my lord, enter.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm
Invades us to the skin: so 'tis to thee;
But where the greater malady is fixed,
The lesser is scarce felt. Thou'ldst shun a bear;
But if thy flight lay toward the roaring sea,
Thou'ldst meet the bear i' the mouth. When the mind's free,
The body's delicate: this tempest in my mind
Doth from my senses take all feeling else
Save what beats there. Filial ingratitude!
Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
For lifting food to't? But I will punish home:
No, I will weep no more. In such a night
To shut me out! Pour on; I will endure.
In such a night as this! O Regan, Goneril!
Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all, —
O, that way madness lies; let me shun that;
No more of that.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Good my lord, enter here.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Prithee, go in thyself; seek thine own ease:
This tempest will not give me leave to ponder
On things would hurt me more. But I'll go in.
To the Fool In, boy; go first. You houseless poverty, —
Nay, get thee in. I'll pray, and then I'll sleep. Fool goes in.
Poor naked wretches, wheresoe'er you are,
That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm,
How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides,
Your looped and windowed raggedness, defend you
From seasons such as these? O, I have ta'en
Too little care of this! Take physic, pomp;
Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel,
That thou mayst shake the superflux to them,
And show the heavens more just.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Fathom and half, fathom and half! Poor Tom!
sp.stage: The Fool runs out from the hovel.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Come not in here, nuncle, here's a spirit. Help me,
help me!

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: Give me thy hand. Who's there?

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: A spirit, a spirit: he says his name's poor Tom.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: What art thou that dost grumble there i' th' straw?
Come forth.
sp.stage: Enter EDGAR disguised as a madman.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Away! the foul fiend follows me! Through the
sharp hawthorn blow the cold winds. Hum! go to thy
bed, and warm thee.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Didst thou give all to thy daughters? And art thou
come to this?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Who gives any thing to poor Tom? whom the foul
fiend hath led through fire and through flame,
through ford and whirlpool, o'er bog and quagmire;
that hath laid knives under his pillow, and
halters in his pew; set ratsbane by his porridge;
made him proud of heart, to ride on a bay
trotting-horse over four-inched bridges, to course
his own shadow for a traitor. Bless thy five
wits! Tom's a-cold, — O, do de, do de, do de. Bless
thee from whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking!
Do poor Tom some charity, whom the foul fiend
vexes: there could I have him now, — and there, — and
there again, and there.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Has his daughters brought him to this pass?
Couldst thou save nothing? Wouldst thou give 'em all?

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Nay, he reserved a blanket, else we had been all
shamed.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Now, all the plagues that in the pendulous air
Hang fated o'er men's faults light on thy daughters!

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: He hath no daughters, sir.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Death, traitor! nothing could have subdued nature
To such a lowness but his unkind daughters.
Is it the fashion, that discarded fathers
Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?
Judicious punishment! 'twas this flesh begot
Those pelican daughters.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Pillicock sat on Pillicock-hill:
Halloo, halloo, loo, loo!

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Take heed o' the foul fiend: obey thy parents;
keep thy word's justice; swear not; commit not
with man's sworn spouse; set not thy sweet heart on
proud array. Tom's a-cold.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: What hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: A servingman, proud in heart and mind; that curled
my hair; wore gloves in my cap; served the lust
of my mistress' heart, and did the act of darkness
with her; swore as many oaths as I spake words,
and broke them in the sweet face of heaven: one
that slept in the contriving of lust, and waked
to do it: wine loved I deeply, dice dearly; and
in woman out-paramoured the Turk: false of heart,
light of ear, bloody of hand; hog in sloth, fox
in stealth, wolf in greediness, dog in madness,
lion in prey. Let not the creaking of shoes nor
the rustling of silks betray thy poor heart to
woman: keep thy foot out of brothels, thy hand
out of plackets, thy pen from lenders' books,
and defy the foul fiend. Still through the hawthorn
blows the cold wind: Says suum, mun, nonny. Dolphin my
boy, boy, sessa! let him trot by.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Thou wert better in a grave than to answer with
thy uncovered body this extremity of the skies.
Is man no more than this? Consider him well. Thou
owest the worm no silk, the beast no hide, the
sheep no wool, the cat no perfume. Ha! here's
three on's are sophisticated! Thou art the thing
itself: unaccommodated man is no more but such
a poor, bare, forked animal as thou art. Off, off, you
lendings! come, unbutton here.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Prithee, nuncle, be contented; 'tis a naughty
night to swim in. Now a little fire in a wild
field were like an old lecher's heart; a small
spark, all the rest on's body cold. Look, here comes
a walking fire.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet: he begins
at curfew, and walks till the first cock; he
gives the web and the pin, squinies the eye, and
makes the hare-lip; mildews the white wheat, and hurts
the poor creature of earth.

lg.l: Swithold footed thrice the 'old;
He met the night-mare, and her nine-fold;
Bid her alight,
And her troth plight,
And, aroint thee, witch, aroint thee!

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: How fares your grace?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: What's he?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: Who's there? What is't you seek?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.ab: What are you there? Your names?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Poor Tom; that eats the swimming frog, the toad,
the tadpole, the wall-newt and the water; that
in the fury of his heart, when the foul fiend
rages, eats cow-dung for sallets; swallows the
old rat and the ditch-dog; drinks the green mantle
of the standing pool; who is whipped from tithing
to tithing, and stock-punished, and imprisoned;
who hath had three suits to his back, six shirts to
his body,

lg.l: Horse to ride, and weapon to wear;
But mice and rats, and such small deer,
Have been Tom's food for seven long year.

sp.ab: Beware my follower. Peace, Smulkin; peace, thou fiend!

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: What, hath your grace no better company?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: The prince of darkness is a gentleman: Modo he's
called, and Mahu.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Our flesh and blood, my lord, is grown so vile,
That it doth hate what gets it.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Poor Tom's a-cold.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Go in with me: my duty cannot suffer
To obey in all your daughters' hard commands:
Though their injunction be to bar my doors,
And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you,
Yet have I ventured to come seek you out,
And bring you where both fire and food is ready.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: First let me talk with this philosopher.
What is the cause of thunder?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Good my lord, take his offer; go into the house.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: I'll talk a word with this same learned Theban.
What is your study?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: How to prevent the fiend, and to kill vermin.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Let me ask you one word in private.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Importune him once more to go, my lord;
His wits begin to unsettle.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Canst thou blame him? Storm still.
His daughters seek his death; ah, that good Kent!
He said it would be thus, poor banished man!
Thou say'st the king grows mad; I'll tell thee, friend.
I am almost mad myself: I had a son,
Now outlawed from my blood: he sought my life,
But lately, very late: I loved him, friend:
No father his son dearer: true to tell thee,
The grief hath crazed my wits. What a night's this!
I do beseech your grace, —

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: O, cry you mercy, sir.
Noble philosopher, your company.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Tom's a-cold.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: In, fellow, there, into the hovel: keep thee warm.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Come, let's in all.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: This way, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: With him;
I will keep still with my philosopher.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Good my lord, soothe him; let him take the fellow.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Take him you on.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Sirrah, come on; go along with us.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Come, good Athenian.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: No words, no words: hush.

lg.l: Child Rowland to the dark tower came,
His word was still, — Fie, foh, and fum,
I smell the blood of a British man. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.ab: I will have my revenge ere I depart his house.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.ab: How, my lord, I may be censured, that nature thus
gives way to loyalty, something fears me to think of.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.ab: I now perceive, it was not altogether your
brother's evil disposition made him seek his
death; but a provoking merit set a-work by a
reproveable badness in himself.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.ab: How malicious is my fortune that I must repent
to be just! This is the letter which he spoke
of, which approves him an intelligent party to
the advantages of France. O heavens! that this treason
were not, or not I the detector!

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.ab: Go with me to the duchess.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.ab: If the matter of this paper be certain, you have
mighty business in hand.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.ab: True or false, it hath made thee earl of Gloucester.
Seek out where thy father is, that he may be ready for
our apprehension.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.ab: If I find him comforting the king. it will stuff
his suspicion more fully. — I will persever in my
course of loyalty, though the conflict be sore between
that and my blood.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.ab: I will lay trust upon thee; and thou shalt find a
dearer father in my love.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 6
div.stage: A chamber in a farmhouse adjoining the castle.
Enter GLOUCESTER, LEAR, KENT, Fool, and EDGAR.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.ab: Here is better than the open air; take it
thankfully. I will piece out the comfort with what
addition I can: I will not be long from you.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: All the power of his wits have given way to his
impatience: the gods reward your kindness!

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Frateretto calls me; and tells me Nero is an
angler in the lake of darkness. Pray, innocent, and
beware the foul fiend.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Prithee, nuncle, tell me whether a madman be a
gentleman or a yeoman?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: A king, a king!

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: No, he's a yeoman that has a gentleman to his
son; for he's a mad yeoman that sees his son a
gentleman before him.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: To have a thousand with red burning spits
Come hissing in upon 'em, —

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: The foul fiend bites my back.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: He's mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf, a
horse's health, a boy's love, or a whore's oath.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: It shall be done; I will arraign them straight.
To Edgar Come, sit thou here, most learned justicer;
To the Fool Thou, sapient sir, sit here. Now, you she-foxes!

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Look, where he stands and glares! Want'st thou
eyes at trial, madam? “Come o'er the bourn, Bessy, to
me, —”

lg.l: Her boat hath a leak,
And she must not speak
Why she dares not come over to thee.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: The foul fiend haunts poor Tom in the voice of
a nightingale. Hopdance cries in Tom's belly for
two white herring. Croak not, black angel; I have no
food for thee.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: How do you, sir? Stand you not so amazed:
Will you lie down and rest upon the cushions?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: I'll see their trial first. Bring in their evidence.
To Edgar Thou robed man of justice, take thy place;
To the Fool And thou, his yoke-fellow of equity,
Bench by his side: To Kent you are o' the commission,
Sit you too.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Let us deal justly.

lg.l: Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd?
Thy sheep be in the corn;
And for, one blast of thy minikin mouth,
Thy sheep shall take no harm.

sp.ab: Purr! the cat is grey.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Arraign her first: 'tis Goneril. I here take my
oath before this honourable assembly, she kicked the
poor king her father.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Come hither, mistress. Is your name Goneril?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: She cannot deny it.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Cry you mercy, I took you for a joint-stool.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: And here's another, whose warped looks proclaim
What store her heart is made an. Stop her there!
Arms, arms, sword, fire! Corruption in the place!
False justicer, why hast thou let her scape?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Bless thy five wits!

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: O pity! Sir, where is the patience now,
That you so oft have boasted to retain?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Aside My tears begin to take his part so much,
They mar my counterfeiting.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: The little dogs and all,
Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart, see, they bark at me.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Tom will throw his head at them. Avaunt, you curs!

lg.l: Be thy mouth or black or white,
Tooth that poisons if it bite;
Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel grim,
Hound or spaniel, brach or lym,
Or bobtail tike or trundle-tail,
Tom will make him weep and wail:
For, with throwing thus my head.
Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled.

sp.ab: Do de, de, de. Sessa! Come, march to wakes and fairs
and market towns. Poor Tom, thy horn is dry.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Then let them anatomize Regan; see what breeds
about her heart. Is there any cause in nature
that make these hard hearts?
You, sir, I entertain for one of my hundred; only
I do not like the fashion of your garments: you will
say they are Persian, but let them be changed.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Make no noise, make no noise; draw the curtains: so,
so. We'll go to supper i' the morning.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: And I'll go to bed at noon.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Come hither, friend: where is the king my master?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Here, sir; but trouble him not, his wits are gone.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Good friend, I prithee, take him in thy arms;
I have o'erheard a plot of death upon him:
There is a litter ready; lay him in't,
And drive towards Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet
Both welcome and protection. Take up thy master:
If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life,
With thine, and all that offer to defend him,
Stand in assured loss: take up, take up;
And follow me, that will to some provision
Give thee quick conduct.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Oppressed nature sleeps:
This rest might yet have balmed thy broken sinews,
Which, if convenience will not allow,
Thou must not stay behind.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Come, come, away. Exeunt all but Edgar.

sp.speaker: Edgar

lg.l: When we our betters see bearing our woes,
We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
Who alone suffers suffers most i' the mind,
Leaving free things and happy shows behind:
But then the mind much sufferance doth o'erskip,
When grief hath mates, and bearing fellowship.
How light and portable my pain seems now,
When that which makes me bend makes the king bow,
He childed as I fathered! Tom, away!
Mark the high noises; and thyself bewray,
When false opinion, whose wrong thoughts defile thee,
In thy just proof, repeals and reconciles thee.

sp.l: What will hap more to-night, safe scape the king!
Lurk, lurk. Exit.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 7
div.stage: Enter CORNWALL, REGAN, GONERIL, EDMUND, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.ab: Post speedily to my lord your husband; show him
this letter: the army of France is landed. Seek out
the traitor Gloucester.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.ab: Hang him instantly.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.ab: Pluck out his eyes.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.ab: Leave him to my displeasure. Edmund, keep you
our sister company: the revenges we are bound to
take upon your traitorous father are not fit for
your beholding. Advise the duke, where you are
going, to a most festinate preparation: we are
bound to the like. Our posts shall be swift and
intelligent betwixt us. Farewell, dear sister:
farewell, my lord of Gloucester.
How now! where's the king?

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: My lord of Gloucester hath conveyed him hence:
Some five or six and thirty of his knights,
Hot questrists after him, met him at gate;
Who, with some other of the lord's dependents,
Are gone with him towards Dover; where they boast
To have well-armed friends.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Get horses for your mistress.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Edmund, farewell. Exeunt Goneril, Edmund, and Oswald. Go seek the traitor Gloucester,
Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us. Exeunt other Servants.
Though well we may not pass upon his life
Without the form of justice, yet our power
Shall do a courtesy to our wrath, which men
May blame, but not control. Who's there? the traitor? Enter GLOUCESTER, brought in by two or three.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Ingrateful fox! 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Bind fast his corky arms.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: What means your graces? Good my friends, consider
You are my guests: do me no foul play, friends.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Bind him, I say. Servants bind him.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Hard, hard. O filthy traitor!

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Unmerciful lady as you are, I'm none.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: To this chair bind him. Villain, thou shalt find — Regan plucks his beard.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: By the kind gods, 'tis most ignobly done
To pluck me by the beard.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: So white, and such a traitor!

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Naughty lady,
These hairs, which thou dost ravish from my chin,
Will quicken, and accuse thee: I am your host:
With robber's hands my hospitable favours
You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Come, sir, what letters had you late from France?

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Be simple-answered, for we know the truth.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: And what confederacy have you with the traitors
Late footed in the kingdom?

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: To whose hands you have sent the lunatic king?
Speak.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: I have a letter guessingly set down,
Which came from one that's of a neutral heart,
And not from one opposed.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Cunning.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: And false.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Where hast thou sent the king?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: To Dover.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charged at peril —

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Wherefore to Dover? Let him answer that.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: I am tied to the stake, and I must stand the course.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Wherefore to Dover?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Because I would not see thy cruel nails
Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister
In his anointed flesh rash boarish fangs.
The sea, with such a storm as his bare head
In hell-black night endured, would have buoyed up,
And quenched the stelled fires:
Yet, poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.
If wolves had at thy gate howled that dearn time,
Thou shouldst have said “Good porter, turn the key,”
All cruels else subscribe: but I shall see
The winged vengeance overtake such children.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: See't shalt thou never. Fellows, hold the chair.
Upon these eyes of thine I'll set my foot.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: He that will think to live till he be old,
Give me some help! O cruel! O you gods!

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: One side will mock another; the other too.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: If you see vengeance, —

sp.speaker: First Servant
sp.l: Hold your hand, my lord:
I have served you ever since I was a child;
But better service have I never done you
Than now to bid you hold.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: How now, you dog!

sp.speaker: First Servant
sp.l: If you did wear a beard upon your chin,
I'd shake it on this quarrel. What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: My villain! They draw and fight.

sp.speaker: First Servant
sp.l: Nay, then, come on, and take the chance of anger.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Give me thy sword. A peasant stand up thus! Takes a sword, and runs at him behind.

sp.speaker: First Servant
sp.l: O, I am slain! My lord, you have one eye left
To see some mischief on him. O! Dies.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Lest it see more, prevent it. Out, vile jelly!
Where is thy lustre now?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: All dark and comfortless. Where's my son Edmund?
Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of nature,
To quit this horrid act.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Out, treacherous villain!
Thou call'st on him that hates thee: it was he
That made the overture of thy treasons to us;
Who is too good to pity thee.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: O my follies! then Edgar was abused.
Kind gods, forgive me that, and prosper him!

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell
His way to Dover. Exit one with Gloucester. How is't, my lord? how look you?

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: I have received a hurt: follow me, lady.
Turn out that eyeless villain; throw this slave
Upon the dunghill. Regan, I bleed apace:
Untimely comes this hurt: give me your arm. Exit Cornwall, led by Regan.

sp.speaker: Second Servant
sp.l: I'll never care what wickedness I do,
If this man come to good.

sp.speaker: Third Servant
sp.l: If she live long,
And in the end meet the old course of death,
Women will all turn monsters.

sp.speaker: Second Servant
sp.l: Let's follow the old earl, and get the Bedlam
To lead him where he would: his roguish madness
Allows itself to any thing.

sp.speaker: Third Servant
sp.l: Go thou: I'll fetch some flax and whites of eggs
To apply to his bleeding face. Now, heaven help him! Exeunt severally.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Yet better thus, and known to be contemned,
Than still contemned and flattered. To be worst,
The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune,
Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear:
The lamentable change is from the best;
The worst returns to laughter. Welcome, then,
Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!
The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst
Owes nothing to thy blasts. But who comes here? Enter GLOUCESTER, led by Old Man.
My father, parti-eyed? World, world, O world!
But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,
Life would not yield to age.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: O, my good lord,
I have been your tenant, and your father's tenant,
These fourscore years.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Away, get thee away; good friend, be gone:
Thy comforts can do me no good at all;
Thee they may hurt.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: You cannot see your way.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes;
I stumbled when I saw: full oft 'tis seen,
Our means secure us, and our mere defects
Prove our commodities. O dear son Edgar,
The food of thy abused father's wrath!
Might I but live to see thee in my touch,
I'ld say I had eyes again!

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: How now! Who's there?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Aside O gods! Who is't can say “I am at the worst”?
I am worse than e'er I was.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: 'Tis poor mad Tom.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Aside And worse I may be yet: the worst is not
So long as we can say “This is the worst.”

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: Fellow, where goest?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Is it a beggar-man?

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: Madman and beggar too.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: He has some reason, else he could not beg.
I' the last night's storm I such a fellow saw;
Which made me think a man a worm: my son
Came then into my mind; and yet my mind
Was then scarce friends with him: I have heard more since.
As flies to wanton boys, are we to the gods,
They kill us for their sport.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Aside How should this be?
Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow,
Angering itself and others. — Bless thee, master!

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Is that the naked fellow?

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Then, prithee, get thee away: if, for my sake,
Thou wilt o'ertake us, hence a mile or twain,
I' the way toward Dover, do it for ancient love;
And bring some covering for this naked soul,
Which I'll entreat to lead me.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: Alack, sir, he is mad.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: 'Tis the time's plague, when madmen lead the blind.
Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure;
Above the rest, be gone.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: I'll bring him the best 'parel that I have,
Come on't what will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Sirrah, naked fellow, —

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Poor Tom's a-cold. Aside I cannot daub it further.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Come hither, fellow.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: And yet I must. — Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Know'st thou the way to Dover?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Both stile and gate, horse-way and foot-path.
Poor Tom hath been scared out of his good wits:
bless thee, good man's son, from the foul fiend!
five fiends have been in poor Tom at once; of
lust, as Obidicut; Hobbididance, prince of
dumbness; Mahu, of stealing; Modo, of murder;
Flibbertigibbet, of mopping and mowing, who since
possesses chambermaids and waiting-women. So, bless
thee, master!

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Here, take this purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues
Have humbled to all strokes: that I am wretched
Makes thee the happier: heavens, deal so still!
Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,
That slaves your ordinance, that will not see
Because he does not feel, feel your power quickly;
So distribution should undo excess,
And each man have enough. Dost thou know Dover?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Ay, master.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: There is a cliff, whose high and bending head
Looks fearfully in the confined deep:
Bring me but to the very brim of it,
And I'll repair the misery thou dost bear
With something rich about me: from that place
I shall no leading need.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Give me thy arm:
Poor Tom shall lead thee. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 2
div.stage: Before the Duke of Albany's palace.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Welcome, my lord: I marvel our mild husband
Not met us on the way. Enter OSWALD. Now, where's your master?

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: Madam, within; but never man so changed.
I told him of the army that was landed;
He smiled at it: I told him you were coming;
His answer was “The worse:” of Gloucester's treachery,
And of the loyal service of his son,
When I informed him, then he called me sot,
And told me I had turned the wrong side out:
What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him;
What like, offensive.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Then shall you go no further.
It is the cowish terror of his spirit,
That dares not undertake: he'll not feel wrongs
Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way
May prove effects. Back, Edmund, to my brother;
Hasten his musters and conduct his powers:
I must change names at home, and give the distaff
Into my husband's hands. This trusty servant
Shall pass between us: ere long you are like to hear,
If you dare venture in your own behalf,
A mistress's command. Wear this; spare speech; Giving a favour.
Decline your head: this kiss, if it durst speak,
Would stretch thy spirits up into the air:
Conceive, and fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Yours in the ranks of death.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: My most dear Gloucester! Exit Edmund.
O, the difference of man and man!
To thee a woman's services are due:
A fool usurps my bed.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: Madam, here comes my lord. Exit. Enter ALBANY.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: I have been worth the whistling.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: O Goneril!
You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blows in your face. I fear your disposition:
That nature, which contemns it origin,
Cannot be bordered certain in itself;
She that herself will sliver and disbranch
From her material sap, perforce must wither
And come to deadly use.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: No more; the text is foolish.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile:
Filths savour but themselves. What have you done?
Tigers, not daughters, what have you performed?
A father, and a gracious aged man,
Whose reverence even the head-lugged bear would lick,
Most barbarous, most degenerate! have you madded.
Could my good brother suffer you to do it?
A man, a prince, by him so benefited!
If that the heavens do not their visible spirits
Send quickly down to tame these vile offences,
It will come,
Humanity must perforce prey on itself,
Like monsters of the deep.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Milk-livered man!
That bear'st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs:
Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning
Thine honour from thy suffering; that not know'st
Fools do those villains pity who are punished
Ere they have done their mischief. Where's thy drum?
France spreads his banners in our noiseless land,
With plumed helm thy state begins to threat;
Whilst thou, a moral fool, sits still, and cries
“Alack, why does he so?”

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: See thyself, devil!
Proper deformity shows not in the fiend
So horrid as in woman.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: O vain fool!

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Thou changed and self-covered thing, for shame,
Be-monster not thy feature. Were't my fitness
To let these hands obey my blood,
They are apt enough to dislocate and tear
Thy flesh and bones: howe'er thou art a fiend,
A woman's shape doth shield thee.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Marry, your manhood mew — Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: O, my good lord, the Duke of Cornwall's dead;
Slain by his servant, going to put out
The other eye of Gloucester.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Gloucester's eyes!

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: A servant that he bred, thrilled with remorse,
Opposed against the act, bending his sword
To his great master; who, thereat enraged,
Flew on him, and amongst them felled him dead;
But not without that harmful stroke, which since
Hath plucked him after.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: This shows you are above,
You justicers, that these our nether crimes
So speedily can venge! But, O poor Gloucester
Lost he his other eye?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Both, both, my lord.
This letter, madam, craves a speedy answer;
'Tis from your sister.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Aside One way I like this well;
But being widow, and my Gloucester with her,
May all the building in my fancy pluck
Upon my hateful life: another way,
The news is not so tart. — I'll read, and answer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Where was his son when they did take his eyes?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Come with my lady hither.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: No, my good lord; I met him back again.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Knows he the wickedness?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Ay, my good lord; 'twas he informed against him;
And quit the house on purpose, that their punishment
Might have the freer course.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Gloucester, I live
To thank thee for the love thou showedst the king,
And to revenge thine eyes. Come hither, friend:
Tell me what more thou know'st. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back know
you no reason?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.ab: Something he left imperfect in the state, which
since his coming forth is thought of; which
imports to the kingdom so much fear and danger,
that his personal return was most required and
necessary.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: Who hath he left behind him general?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.ab: The Marshal of France, Monsieur La Far.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: Did your letters pierce the queen to any demonstration
of grief?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Ay, sir; she took them, read them in my presence;
And now and then an ample tear trilled down
Her delicate cheek: it seemed she was a queen
Over her passion; who, most rebel-like,
Sought to be king o'er her.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: O, then it moved her.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Not to a rage: patience and sorrow strove
Who should express her goodliest. You have seen
Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears
Were like a better way: those happy smilets,
That played on her ripe lip, seemed not to know
What guests were in her eyes: which parted thence,
As pearls from diamonds dropped. In brief,
Sorrow would be a rarity most beloved,
If all could so become it.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Made she no verbal question?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: 'Faith, once or twice she heaved the name of “father”
Pantingly forth, as if it pressed her heart:
Cried “Sisters! sisters! Shame of ladies! sisters!
Kent! father! sisters! What, i' the storm? i' the night?
Let pity not be believed!” There she shook
The holy water from her heavenly eyes,
And clamour-moistened: then away she started
To deal with grief alone.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: It is the stars.
The stars above us, govern our conditions;
Else one self mate and make could not beget
Such different issues. You spoke not with her since?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Was this before the king returned?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: No, since.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Well, sir, the poor distressed Lear's i' the town;
Who sometime, in his better tune, remembers
What we are come about, and by no means
Will yield to see his daughter.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Why, good sir?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: A sovereign shame so elbows him: his own unkindness,
That stripped her from his benediction, turned her
To foreign casualties, gave her dear rights
To his dog-hearted daughters, these things sting
His mind so venomously, that burning shame
Detains him from Cordelia.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Alack, poor gentleman

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Of Albany's and Cornwall's powers you heard not?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: 'Tis so, they are afoot.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Well, sir, I'll bring you to our master Lear,
And leave you to attend him: some dear cause
Will in concealment wrap me up awhile;
When I am known aright, you shall not grieve
Lending me this acquaintance. I pray you, go
Along with me. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter, with drum and colours, CORDELIA, Doctor, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: Alack, 'tis he: why, he was met even now
As mad as the vexed sea; singing aloud;
Crowned with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds,
With hardocks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers,
Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow
In our sustaining corn. A century send forth;
Search every acre in the high-grown field,
And bring him to our eye. Exit an Officer. What can man's wisdom
In the restoring his bereaved sense?
He that helps him take all my outward worth.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: There is means, madam:
Our foster-nurse of nature is repose,
The which he lacks; that to provoke in him,
Are many simples operative, whose power
Will close the eye of anguish.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: All blest secrets,
All you unpublished virtues of the earth,
Spring with my tears! be aidant and remediate
In the good man's distress! Seek, seek for him;
Lest his ungoverned rage dissolve the life
That wants the means to lead it. Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: News, madam;
The British powers are marching hitherward.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: 'Tis known before; our preparation stands
In expectation of them. O dear father,
It is thy business that I go about;
Therefore great France
My mourning and importuned tears hath pitied.
No blown ambition doth our arms incite,
But love, dear love and our aged father's right:
Soon may I hear and see him! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: But are my brother's powers set forth?

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Himself in person there?

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: Madam, with much ado:
Your sister is the better soldier.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home?

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: What might import my sister's letter to him?

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: I know not, lady.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: 'Faith, he is posted hence on serious matter.
It was great ignorance, Gloucester's eyes being out,
To let him live: where he arrives he moves
All hearts against us: Edmund, I think, is gone,
In pity of his misery, to dispatch
His nighted life; moreover, to descry
The strength o' the enemy.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: I must needs after him, madam, with my letter.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Our troops set forth to-morrow: stay with us;
The ways are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: I may not, madam:
My lady charged my duty in this business.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Why should she write to Edmund? Might not you
Transport her purposes by word? Belike,
Some things — I know not what: I'll love thee much,
Let me unseal the letter.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: Madam, I had rather —

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: I know your lady does not love her husband;
I am sure of that: and at her late being here
She gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks
To noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosom.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: I, madam?

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: I speak in understanding; you are, I know't:
Therefore I do advise you, take this note:
My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talked;
And more convenient is he for my hand
Than for your lady's: you may gather more.
If you do find him, pray you, give him this;
And when your mistress hears thus much from you,
I pray, desire her call her wisdom to her.
So, fare you well.
If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor,
Preferment falls on him that cuts him off.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: Would I could meet him, madam! I should show
What party I do follow.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Fare thee well. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 6
div.stage: Enter GLOUCESTER, and EDGAR dressed like a peasant.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: When shall I come to the top of that same hill?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: You do climb up it now: look, how we labour.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Methinks the ground is even.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Horrible steep.
Hark, do you hear the sea?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: No, truly.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Why, then, your other senses grow imperfect
By your eyes' anguish.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: So may it be, indeed:
Methinks thy voice is altered; and thou speak'st
In better phrase and matter than thou didst.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Y' are much deceived: in nothing am I changed
But in my garments.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Methinks y' are better spoken.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Come on, sir; here's the place: stand still. How fearful
And dizzy 'tis, to cast one's eyes so low!
The crows and choughs that wing the midway air
Show scarce so gross as beetles: half way down
Hangs one that gathers samphire, dreadful trade!
Methinks he seems no bigger than his head:
The fishermen, that walk upon the beach,
Appear like mice; and yond tall anchoring bark,
Diminished to her cock; her cock, a buoy
Almost too small for sight: the murmuring surge,
That on the unnumbered idle pebble chafes,
Cannot be heard so high. I'll look no more;
Lest my brain turn, and the deficient sight
Topple down headlong.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Set me where you stand.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Give me your hand: you are now within a foot
Of the extreme verge: for all beneath the moon
Would I not leap upright.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Let go my hand.
Here, friend, 's another purse; in it a jewel
Well worth a poor man's taking: fairies and gods
Prosper it with thee Go thou farther off;
Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Now fare ye well, good sir.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Why I do trifle thus with his despair
Is done to cure it.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Kneeling O, you mighty gods!
This world I do renounce, and in your sights,
Shake patiently my great affliction off:
If I could bear it longer, and not fall
To quarrel with your great opposeless wills,
My snuff and loathed part of nature should
Burn itself out. If Edgar live, O, bless him!
Now, fellow, fare thee well. He falls forward.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Gone, sir: farewell.
And yet I know not how conceit may rob
The treasury of life, when life itself
Yields to the theft: had he been where he thought,
By this, had thought been past. Alive or dead?
Ho, you sir! friend! Hear you, sir! speak!
Thus might he pass indeed: yet he revives.
What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Away, and let me die.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air,
So many fathom down precipitating,
Thou'dst shivered like an egg: but thou dost breathe;
Hast heavy substance; bleed'st not; speak'st; art sound.
Ten masts at each make not the altitude
Which thou hast perpendicularly fell:
Thy life's a miracle. Speak yet again.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: But have I fall'n, or no?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: From the dread summit of this chalky bourn.
Look up a-height; the shrill-gorged lark so far
Cannot be seen or heard: do but look up.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Alack, I have no eyes.
Is wretchedness deprived that benefit,
To end itself by death? 'Twas yet some comfort,
When misery could beguile the tyrant's rage,
And frustrate his proud will.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Give me your arm:
Up: so. How is't? Feel you your legs? You stand.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Too well, too well.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: This is above all strangeness.
Upon the crown o' the cliff, what thing was that
Which parted from you?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: A poor unfortunate beggar.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: As I stood here below, methought his eyes
Were two full moons; he had a thousand noses,
Horns whelked and waved like the enridged sea:
It was some fiend; therefore, thou happy father,
Think that the clearest gods, who make them honours
Of men's impossibilities, have preserved thee.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: I do remember now: henceforth I'll bear
Affliction till it do cry out itself
“Enough, enough,” and die. That thing you speak of,
I took it for a man; often 'twould say
“The fiend, the fiend:” he led me to that place.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Bear free and patient thoughts. But who comes here?
sp.stage: Enter LEAR, fantastically dressed with wild flowers.
sp.l: The safer sense will ne'er accommodate
His master thus.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: No, they cannot touch me for coining; I am the king
himself.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: O thou side-piercing sight!

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Nature's above art in that respect. There's your
press-money. That fellow handles his bow like a
crow-keeper: draw me a clothier's yard. Look,
look, a mouse! Peace, peace; this piece of toasted
cheese will do't. There's my gauntlet; I'll prove
it on a giant. Bring up the brown bills. O, well
flown, bird! i' the clout, i' the clout: hewgh! Give
the word.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Sweet marjoram.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Pass.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.ab: I know that voice.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Ha! Goneril, with a white beard! They flattered
me like a dog; and told me I had the white hairs
in my beard ere the black ones were there. To
say “ay” and “no” to every thing that I said! — “Ay”
and “no” too was no good divinity. When the rain
came to wet me once, and the wind to make me
chatter; when the thunder would not peace at my
bidding; there I found 'em, there I smelt 'em
out. Go to, they are not men o' their words: they
told me I was every thing; 'tis a lie, I am not
ague-proof.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: The trick of that voice I do well remember:
Is't not the king?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Ay, every inch a king:
When I do stare, see how the subject quakes.
I pardon that man's life. What was thy cause?
Adultery?
Thou shalt not die: die for adultery! No:
The wren goes to't, and the small gilded fly
Does lecher in my sight.
Let copulation thrive; for Gloucester's bastard son
Was kinder to his father than my daughters
Got 'tween the lawful sheets.
To't, luxury, pell-mell! for I lack soldiers.
Behold yond simpering dame,
Whose face between her forks presages snow;
That minces virtue, and does shake the head
To hear of pleasure's name;
The fitchew, nor the soiled horse, goes to't
With a more riotous appetite.
Down from the waist they are Centaurs,
Though women all above:
But to the girdle do the gods inherit,
Beneath is all the fiends';
There's hell, there's darkness, there is the sulphurous pit,
sp.ab: Burning, scalding, stench, consumption; fie, fie,
fie! pah, pah! Give me an ounce of civet, good
apothecary, sweeten my imagination: there's money for
thee.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: O, let me kiss that hand!

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Let me wipe it first; it smells of mortality.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: O ruined piece of nature! This great world
Shall so wear out to nought. Dost thou know me?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: I remember thine eyes well enough. Dost thou
squiny at me? No, do thy worst, blind Cupid; I'll
not love. Read thou this challenge; mark but the
penning of it.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Were all thy letters suns, I could not see.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: I would not take this from report; it is,
And my heart breaks at it.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Read.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.ab: What, with the case of eyes?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: O, ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your
head, nor no money in your purse? Your eyes are
in a heavy case, your purse in a light: yet you see
how this world goes.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.ab: I see it feelingly.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: What, art mad? A man may see how this world goes
with no eyes. Look with thine ears: see how yond
justice rails upon yond simple thief. Hark, in
thine ear: change places; and, handy-dandy, which
is the justice, which is the thief? Thou hast seen a
farmer's dog bark at a beggar?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.ab: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: And the creature run from the cur? There thou
mightst behold the great image of authority: a dog's
obeyed in office.
sp.l: Thou rascal beadle, hold thy bloody hand!
Why dost thou lash that whore? Strip thy own back;
Thou hotly lusts to use her in that kind
For which thou whipp'st her. The usurer hangs the cozener.
Through tattered clothes small vices do appear;
Robes and furred gowns hide all. Plate sin with gold,
And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks;
Arm it in rags, a pigmy's straw does pierce it.
None does offend, none, I say, none; I'll able 'em:
Take that of me, my friend, who have the power
To seal the accuser's lips. Get thee glass eyes;
And, like a scurvy politician, seem
To see the things thou dost not. Now, now, now, now:
Pull off my boots: harder, harder: so.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: O, matter and impertinency mixed!
Reason in madness!

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.
I know thee well enough; thy name is Gloucester:
Thou must be patient; we came crying hither:
Thou know'st the first time that we smell the air,
We wawl and cry. I will preach to thee: mark.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Alack, alack the day!

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: When we are born, we cry that we are come
To this great stage of fools: this' a good block;
It were a delicate stratagem, to shoe
A troop of horse with felt: I'll put't in proof;
And when I have stol'n upon these son-in-laws,
Then, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill! Enter a Gentleman, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: O, here he is: lay hand upon him. Sir,
Your most dear daughter —

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: No rescue? What, a prisoner? I am even
The natural fool of fortune. Use me well;
You shall have ransom. Let me have surgeons;
I am cut to the brains.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: You shall have any thing.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: No seconds? all myself?
Why, this would make a man a man of salt,
To use his eyes for garden water-pots,
Ay, and laying autumn's dust.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Good sir, —

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: I will die bravely, like a smug bridegroom. What!
I will be jovial: come, come; I am a king,
Masters, know you that.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: You are a royal one, and we obey you.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.ab: Then there's life in't. Come, and you get it, you
shall get it by running. Sa, sa, sa, sa.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch,
Past speaking of in a king! Thou hast one daughter,
Who redeems nature from the general curse
Which twain have brought her to.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Hail, gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Sir, speed you: what's your will?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Do you hear aught, sir, of a battle toward?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Most sure and vulgar: every one hears that,
Which can distinguish sound.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: But, by your favour,
How near's the other army?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Near and on speedy foot; the main descry
Stands on the hourly thought.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: I thank you, sir: that's all.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Though that the queen on special cause is here,
Her army is moved on.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: I thank you, sir. Exit Gent.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: You ever-gentle gods, take my breath from me;
Let not my worser spirit tempt me again
To die before you please!

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Well pray you, father.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Now, good sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: A most poor man, made tame to fortune's blows;
Who, by the art of known and feeling sorrows,
Am pregnant to good pity. Give me your hand,
I'll lead you to some biding.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Hearty thanks:
The bounty and the benison of heaven
To boot, and boot! Enter OSWALD.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: A proclaimed prize! Most happy!
That eyeless head of thine was first framed flesh
To raise my fortunes. Thou old unhappy traitor,
Briefly thyself remember: the sword is out
That must destroy thee.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Now let thy friendly hand
Put strength enough to't. Edgar interposes.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: Wherefore, bold peasant,
Durst thou support a published traitor? Hence;
Lest that the infection of his fortune take
Like hold on thee. Let go his arm.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Chill not let go, zir, without vurther 'cagion.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.ab: Let go, slave, or thou diest!

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Good gentleman, go your gait, and let poor volk
pass. An chud ha' bin zwaggered out of my life,
'twould not ha' bin zo long as 'tis by a vortnight.
Nay, come not near th' old man; keep out, che
vor ye, or ise try whether your costard or my ballow
be the harder: chill be plain with you.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.ab: Out, dunghill!

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.ab: Chill pick your teeth, zir: come; no matter vor your
foins.
sp.stage: They fight, and Edgar knocks him down.

sp.speaker: Oswald
sp.l: Slave, thou hast slain me: villain, take my purse:
If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body;
And give the letters which thou find'st about me
To Edmund earl of Gloucester; seek him out
Upon the English party: O, untimely death!
Death! Dies.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: I know thee well: a serviceable villain;
As duteous to the vices of thy mistress
As badness would desire.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: What, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Sit you down, father; rest you
Let's see these pockets: the letters that he speaks of
May be my friends. He's dead; I am only sorry
He had no other deathsman. Let us see:
Leave, gentle wax; and, manners, blame us not:
To know our enemies' minds, we rip their hearts;
Their papers, is more lawful. Reads
sp.ab: “Let our reciprocal vows be remembered. You have
many opportunities to cut him off: if your will
want not, time and place will be fruitfully
offered. There is nothing done, if he return the
conqueror: then am I the prisoner, and his bed
my gaol; from the loathed warmth whereof deliver
me, and supply the place for your labour.
“Your — wife, so I would say — “Affectionate servant,
“GONERIL.”
sp.l: O indistinguished space of woman's will!
A plot upon her virtuous husband's life;
And the exchange my brother! Here, in the sands,
Thee I'll rake up, the post unsanctified
Of murderous lechers: and in the mature time
With this ungracious paper strike the sight
Of the death-practised duke: for him 'tis well
That of thy death and business I can tell.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: The king is mad: how stiff is my vile sense,
That I stand up, and have ingenious feeling
Of my huge sorrows! Better I were distract:
So should my thoughts be severed from my griefs,
And woes by wrong imaginations lose
The knowledge of themselves.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Give me your hand: Drum afar off.
Far off, methinks, I hear the beaten drum:
Come, father, I'll bestow you with a friend. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 7
div.stage: A tent in the French camp. LEAR on a bed asleep, soft music playing; Gentleman, and others attending.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: O thou good Kent, how shall I live and work,
To match thy goodness? My life will be too short,
And every measure fail me.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: To be acknowledged, madam, is o'erpaid.
All my reports go with the modest truth;
Nor more nor clipped, but so.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: Be better suited:
These weeds are memories of those worser hours:
I prithee, put them off.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Pardon, dear madam;
Yet to be known shortens my made intent:
My boon I make it, that you know me not
Till time and I think meet.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: Then be't so, my good lord. To the Doctor How does the king?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Madam, sleeps still.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: O you kind gods,
Cure this great breach in his abused nature!
The untuned and jarring senses, O, wind up
Of this child-changed father!

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: So please your majesty
That we may wake the king: he hath slept long.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: Be governed by your knowledge, and proceed
I' the sway of your own will. Is he arrayed?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Ay, madam; in the heaviness of sleep
We put fresh garments on him.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Be by, good madam, when we do awake him;
I doubt not of his temperance.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Please you, draw near. Louder the music there!

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: O my dear father! Restoration hang
Thy medicine on my lips; and let this kiss
Repair those violent harms that my two sisters
Have in thy reverence made!

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: Kind and dear princess!

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: Had you not been their father, these white flakes
Did challenge pity of them. Was this a face
To be opposed against the warring winds?
To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder?
In the most terrible and nimble stroke
Of quick, cross lightning? to watch — poor perdu! —
With this thin helm? Mine enemy's dog,
Though he had bit me, should have stood that night
Against my fire; and wast thou fain, poor father,
To hovel thee with swine, and rogues forlorn,
In short and musty straw? Alack, alack!
'Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once
Had not concluded all. He wakes; speak to him.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Madam, do you; 'tis fittest.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: How does my royal lord? How fares your majesty?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: You do me wrong to take me out o' the grave:
Thou art a soul in bliss; but I am bound
Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears
Do scald like molten lead.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: Sir, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: You are a spirit, I know: when did you die?

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: Still, still, far wide!

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: He's scarce awake: let him alone awhile.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Where have I been? Where am I? Fair daylight?
I am mightily abused. I should e'en die with pity,
To see another thus. I know not what to say.
I will not swear these are my hands: let's see;
I feel this pin prick. Would I were assured
Of my condition!

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: O, look upon me, sir,
And hold your hand in benediction o'er me:
No, sir, you must not kneel.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Pray, do not mock me:
I am a very foolish fond old man,
Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less;
And, to deal plainly,
I fear I am not in my perfect mind.
Methinks I should know you, and know this man;
Yet I am doubtful: for I am mainly ignorant
What place this is; and all the skill I have
Remembers not these garments; nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me;
For, as I am a man, I think this lady
To be my child Cordelia.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: And so I am, I am.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Be your tears wet? yes, 'faith. I pray, weep not:
If you have poison for me, I will drink it.
I know you do not love me; for your sisters
Have, as I do remember, done me wrong:
You have some cause, they have not.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: No cause, no cause.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Am I in France?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.l: In your own kingdom, sir.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Do not abuse me.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Be comforted, good madam: the great rage,
You see, is killed in him: and yet it is danger
To make him even o'er the time he has lost.
Desire him to go in; trouble him no more
Till further settling.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: Will't please your highness walk?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: You must bear with me:
Pray you now, forget and forgive: I am old and foolish. Exeunt all but Kent and Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.ab: Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was so
slain?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: Most certain, sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.ab: Who is conductor of his people?

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: As 'tis said, the bastard son of Gloucester.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.ab: They say Edgar, his banished son, is with the Earl of
Kent in Germany.

sp.speaker: Kent
sp.ab: Report is changeable. 'Tis time to look about; the
powers of the kingdom approach apace.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.ab: The arbitrement is like to be bloody. Fare you well,
sir.

lg.l: My point and period will be throughly wrought,
Or well or ill, as this day's battle's fought. Exit.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter, with drum and colours, EDMUND, REGAN, Gentlemen, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Know of the duke if his last purpose hold,
Or whether since he is advised by aught
To change the course: he's full of alteration
And self-reproving: bring his constant pleasure. To a Gentleman, who goes out.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Our sister's man is certainly miscarried.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: 'Tis to be doubted, madam.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Now sweet lord,
You know the goodness I intend upon you:
Tell me — but truly — but then speak the truth,
Do you not love my sister?

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: In honoured love.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: But have you never found my brother's way
To the forfended place?

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: That thought abuses you,

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: I am doubtful that you have been conjunct
And bosomed with her, as far as we call hers.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: No, by mine honour, madam.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: I never shall endure her: dear my lord,
Be not familiar with her.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Fear me not:
She and the duke her husband! Enter, with drum and colours, ALBANY, GONERIL, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Aside I had rather lose the battle than that sister
Should loosen him and me.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Our very loving sister, well be-met.
Sir, this I heard; the king is come to his daughter,
With others whom the rigour of our state
Forced to cry out. Where I could not be honest,
I never yet was valiant: for this business,
It touches us, as France invades our land,
Not bolds the king, with others, whom I fear,
Most just and heavy causes make oppose.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Sir, you speak nobly.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Why is this reasoned?

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Combine together 'gainst the enemy;
For these domestic and particular broils
Are not the question here.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Let's then determine
With the ancient of war on our proceeding.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: I shall attend you presently at your tent.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Sister, you'll go with us?

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: 'Tis most convenient; pray, go with us.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Aside O, ho, I know the riddle. — I will go. As they are going out, enter EDGAR disguised.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: If e'er your grace had speech with man so poor,
Hear me one word.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: I'll overtake you. Speak. Exeunt all but Albany and Edgar.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Before you fight the battle, ope this letter.
If you have victory, let the trumpet sound
For him that brought it: wretched though I seem,
I can produce a champion that will prove
What is avouched there. If you miscarry,
Your business of the world hath so an end,
And machination ceases. Fortune love you!

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Stay till I have read the letter.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: I was forbid it.
When time shall serve, let but the herald cry,
And I'll appear again.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Why, fare thee well: I will o'erlook thy paper. Exit Edgar. Re-enter EDMUND.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: The enemy's in view; draw up your powers.
Here is the guess of their true strength and forces
By diligent discovery; but your haste
Is now urged on you.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: We will greet the time. Exit.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: To both these sisters have I sworn my love;
Each jealous of the other, as the stung
Are of the adder. Which of them shall I take?
Both? one? or neither? Neither can be enjoyed,
If both remain alive: to take the widow
Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril;
And hardly shall I carry out my side,
Her husband being alive. Now then we'll use
His countenance for the battle; which being done,
Let her who would be rid of him devise
His speedy taking off. As for the mercy
Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia,
The battle done, and they within our power,
Shall never see his pardon; for my state
Stands on me to defend, not to debate. Exit.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 2
div.stage: A field between the two camps.
Enter, with drum and colours, LEAR, CORDELIA, and Soldiers, over the stage; and exeunt. Enter EDGAR and GLOUCESTER.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Here, father, take the shadow of this tree
For your good host; pray that the right may thrive:
If ever I return to you again,
I'll bring you comfort.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Grace go with you, sir! Exit Edgar. Alarum and retreat within. Re-enter EDGAR.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Away, old man; give me thy hand; away!
King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter ta'en:
Give me thy hand; come on.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: No farther, sir; a man may rot even here.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: What, in ill thoughts again? Men must endure
Their going hence, even as their coming hither:
Ripeness is all: come on.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: And that's true too. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter, in conquest, with drum and colours, EDMUND; LEAR and CORDELIA, prisoners; Captains, Soldiers, etc.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Some officers take them away: good guard,
Until their greater pleasures first be known
That are to censure them.

sp.speaker: Cordelia
sp.l: We are not the first
Who, with best meaning, have incurred the worst.
For thee, oppressed king, I am cast down;
Myself could else out-frown false fortune's frown.
Shall we not see these daughters and these sisters?

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: No, no, no, no! Come, let's away to prison:
We two alone will sing like birds i' the cage:
When thou dost ask me blessing, I'll kneel down,
And ask of thee forgiveness: so we'll live,
And pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh
At gilded butterflies, and hear poor rogues
Talk of court news; and we'll talk with them too,
Who loses and who wins; who's in, who's out;
And take upon's the mystery of things,
As if we were God's spies: and we'll wear out,
In a walled prison, packs and sects of great ones,
That ebb and flow by the moon.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Take them away.

sp.speaker: Lear
sp.l: Upon such sacrifices, my Cordelia,
The gods themselves throw incense. Have I caught thee?
He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven,
And fire us hence like foxes. Wipe thine eyes;
The good-years shall devour them, flesh and fell,
Ere they shall make us weep: we'll see 'em starved first.
Come. Exeunt Lear and Cordelia, guarded.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Come hither, captain; hark.
One step I have advanced thee; if thou dost
As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way
To noble fortunes: know thou this, that men
Are as the time is: to be tender-minded
Does not become a sword: thy great employment
Will not bear question; either say thou'lt do't,
Or thrive by other means.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'll do't, my lord.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: About it; and write happy when thou hast done.
Mark, I say, instantly; and carry it so
As I have set it down.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I cannot draw a cart, nor eat dried oats;
If it be man's work, I'll do't. Exit. Flourish. Enter ALBANY, GONERIL, REGAN, another Captain, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Sir, you have shown to-day your valiant strain,
And fortune led you well: you have the captives
Who were the opposites of this day's strife:
I do require them of you, so to use them
As we shall find their merits and our safety
May equally determine.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Sir, I thought it fit
To send the old and miserable king
To some retention and appointed guard;
Whose age had charms in it, whose title more,
To pluck the common bosom on his side,
And turn our impressed lances in our eyes
Which do command them. With him I sent the queen;
My reason all the same; and they are ready
To-morrow, or at further space, to appear
Where you shall hold your session. At this time
We sweat and bleed: the friend hath lost his friend;
And the best quarrels, in the heat are cursed
By those that feel their sharpness:
The question of Cordelia and her father
Requires a fitter place.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Sir, by your patience,
I hold you but a subject of this war,
Not as a brother.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: That's as we list to grace him.
Methinks our pleasure might have been demanded,
Ere you had spoke so far. He led our powers;
Bore the commission of my place and person;
The which immediacy may well stand up,
And call itself your brother.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Not so hot:
In his own grace he doth exalt himself,
More than in your addition.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: In my rights,
By me invested, he compeers the best.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: That were the most, if he should husband you.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Jesters do oft prove prophets.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Holla, holla!
That eye that told you so looked but a-squint.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Lady, I am not well; else I should answer
From a full-flowing stomach. General,
Take thou my soldiers, prisoners, patrimony;
Dispose of them, of me; the walls is thine:
Witness the world, that I create thee here
My lord and master.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Mean you to enjoy him?

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: The let-alone lies not in your good will.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Nor in thine, lord.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Half-blooded fellow, yes.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Let the drum strike, and prove my title thine.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Stay yet; hear reason. Edmund, I arrest thee
On capital treason; and, in thy attaint,
This gilded serpent . pointing to Gon. For your claim, fair sister,
I bar it in the interest of my wife:
'Tis she is sub-contracted to this lord,
And I, her husband, contradict your banns.
If you will marry, make your loves to me,
My lady is bespoke.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: An interlude!

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Thou art armed, Gloucester: let the trumpet sound:
If none appear to prove upon thy person
Thy heinous, manifest, and many treasons,
There is my pledge ; throwing down a glove
I'll make it on thy heart,
Ere I taste bread, thou art in nothing less
Than I have here proclaimed thee.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: Sick, O, sick!

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: If not, I'll ne'er trust medicine.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: There's my exchange : throwing down down a glove what in the world he is
That names me traitor, villain-like he lies:
Call by the trumpet: he that dares approach,
On him, on you, who not? I will maintain
My truth and honour firmly.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: A herald, ho!

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: A herald, ho, a herald!

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Trust to thy single virtue; for thy soldiers,
All levied in my name, have in my name
Took their discharge.

sp.speaker: Regan
sp.l: My sickness grows upon me.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: She is not well; convey her to my tent. Exit Regan, led. Enter a Herald.
Come hither, herald, — Let the trumpet sound, —
And read out this.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Sound, trumpet! A trumpet sounds.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.ab: “If any man of quality or degree within the lists
of the army will maintain upon Edmund, supposed
Earl of Gloucester, that he is a manifold traitor,
let him appear by the third sound of the trumpet: he
is bold in his defence.”

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Sound! First trumpet.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.l: Again! Second trumpet.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.l: Again! Third trumpet. Trumpet answers within. Enter EDGAR, at the third sound, armed, with a trumpet before him.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Ask him his purposes, why he appears
Upon this call o' the trumpet.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.l: What are you?
Your name, your quality? and why you answer
This present summons?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Know, my name is lost;
By treason's tooth bare-gnawn and canker-bit:
Yet am I noble as the adversary
I come to cope.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Which is that adversary?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: What's he that speaks for Edmund Earl of Gloucester?

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: Himself: what say'st thou to him?

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Draw thy sword,
That, if my speech offend a noble heart,
Thy arm may do thee justice: here is mine.
Behold, it is my privilege
The privilege of mine honours,
My oath, and my profession: I protest,
Maugre thy strength, place, youth, and eminence,
Despite thy victor-sword and fire-new fortune,
Thy valour and thy heart, thou art a traitor;
False to thy gods, thy brother, and thy father;
Conspirant 'gainst this high illustrious prince;
And, from the extremest upward of thy head
To the descent and dust below thy foot,
A most toad-spotted traitor. Say thou “No,”
This sword, this arm, and my best spirits, are bent
To prove upon thy heart, whereto I speak,
Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: In wisdom I should ask thy name;
But, since thy outside looks so fair and warlike,
And that thy tongue some say of breeding breathes,
What safe and nicely I might well delay
By rule of knighthood, I disdain and spurn:
Back do I toss these treasons to thy head;
With the hell-hated lie o'erwhelm thy heart;
Which, for they yet glance by and scarcely bruise,
This sword of mine shall give them instant way,
Where they shall rest for ever. Trumpets, speak! Alarums. They fight. Edmund falls.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Save him, save him!

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: This is practice, Gloucester:
By the law of war thou wast not bound to answer
An unknown opposite; thou art not vanquished,
But cozened and beguiled.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Shut your mouth, dame,
Or with this paper shall I stopple it. Hold, sir;
Thou worse than any name, read thine own evil:
No tearing, lady; I perceive you know it. Gives the letter to Edmund.

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Say, if I do, the laws are mine, not thine:
Who can arraign me for't?

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Most monstrous! o!
Know'st thou this paper?

sp.speaker: Goneril
sp.l: Ask me not what I know. Exit.

sp.speaker: Albany
sp.l: Go after her: she's desperate; govern her.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: What you have charged me with, that have I done;
And more, much more; the time will bring it out:
'Tis past, and so am I. But what art thou
That hast this fortune on me? If thou'rt noble,
I do forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Edgar
sp.l: Let's exchange charity.
I am no less in blood than thou art, Edmund;
If more, the more thou hast wronged me.
